details.title: Details
details.modal-info:
# APPROVED RENT PRICE FORMATION

## **Free Rent Price**  
The amount of the free rent price is determined by supply and demand in the market.  
A review of the appropriateness of the free rent price by the court or the arbitration board is not possible.  

A free rent price formation applies when:  

 **1. You conclude a long-term rental agreement (longer than 6 months).**  
 **2. Your property is not operated as a home, a humanitarian organization,**  
   an accommodation, parking facility, transport, airport operations,  
   forwarding, or warehouse company.  
 **3. One of the following conditions is met:**  
   -   Your property is located in a privately financed building,  
       constructed after **1953** without public funding.  
   -   Your property is an attic conversion or extension,  
       for which the building permit was issued after **31.12.2001**.  
   -   Your property is an annex,  
       for which the building permit was issued after **30.09.2006**.  
   -   Your property is under condominium ownership and located in a building,  
       constructed after the building permit was issued on **08.05.1945**.  
   -   Your property is a **single-family or two-family house**.  
   -   Your property is a **second home for recreational purposes** (secondary residence).  
   -   Your property is a **service apartment**.  

## **Regulated Rent Price**  
For all other properties, a **regulated rent price formation** applies.  

A regulated rent price is one whose amount and increase possibilities  
are explicitly regulated in the Tenancy Act **(MRG)**.  
A range of rent types falls under **regulated rent price**.

a1.title: Exclusive Brokerage Agreement
a1.descriptions:
An Exclusive Brokerage Agreement is a contractual arrangement between a property owner and a real estate agent in which the agent commits to finding a buyer or tenant for the property within a specific timeframe. It stipulates that only this agent is authorized to handle the transaction.

Such an agreement offers advantages for both parties:

The owner receives maximum market exposure through targeted marketing of the property.
The agent invests more resources into marketing, knowing they are the sole recipient of the commission.
The property is not listed by multiple agents simultaneously, reducing the risk of price distortions or fraudulent offers.
Legal Basis and Terms
● The duration of an exclusive brokerage agreement is typically between 3 and 6 months.
● Early termination is usually only possible under specific conditions, such as the agent failing to fulfill their obligations.
● After the contract expires, the owner may choose to extend the contract or sell/rent the property independently or through other agents.

Example for Austria:
○ If an agent is engaged under an exclusive brokerage agreement, the owner cannot sell or rent the property independently without paying the agent the agreed commission.
○ If the agent fails to find a buyer or tenant within the contract period, the agreement expires without cost to the owner.
○ The agent's commission is only payable upon successful completion of the transaction.

Responsible Authority: The Austrian Chamber of Commerce or the respective real estate regulatory authority.

a2.title: Foreign land acquisition
a2.descriptions:
In principle, any natural or legal person, including foreigners, can acquire real estate in Austria. However, the specifics of Austrian law must be taken into account.

Who is allowed to acquire and use specific land plots (real estate) is regulated in Austria under the Land Transfer Act.

Austrian land transfer laws are enacted at the state level, meaning there are 9 different versions corresponding to the number of federal states.

The Federal Land Transfer Act distinguishes 4 types of land transactions:
	1. Agricultural and forestry land transactions (green land transactions)
	2. Transactions involving building plots (gray land transactions)
	3. Foreign land transactions
	4. Transactions involving sea surfaces (blue land transactions)

Foreign land transactions.
If foreigners acquire ownership or co-ownership of real estate, an official permit is generally required. However, there are exceptions for citizens of EU and EEA member states; these individuals are treated as locals and do not require approval.

For nationals of third countries, a permit procedure is usually required. In some cases, citizens of certain third countries can acquire real estate without a permit based on bilateral agreements. In such cases, confirmation is required to ensure that no permit is needed.

Nationals of third countries are considered to be those from countries that are neither members of the European Union (EU) nor signatories to the Agreement on the European Economic Area (EEA).

The approval process can take between 3 and 6 months and involves additional costs.

Example for Vienna (as of 21.04.2024):
•	Approval issuance:
o	76.30 euros administrative fee per applicant for acquiring ownership (co-ownership)
o	47.23 euros administrative fee per applicant for acquiring a personal servitude right (e.g., applying for a right of residence and use for a family member)
•	Legal force clause:
o	3.27 euros administrative fee
o	14.30 euros federal fee
•	Federal fees:
o	14.30 euros per application for each applicant and registration number
o	3.90 euros per attached document copy per page (maximum 21.80 euros)

Competent authority: The office of the respective state government or the respective district administrative authority.

a3.title: Who Orders, Pays" Principle
a3.descriptions:
The Ordering Principle is a legal regulation in German and Austrian rental law that stipulates that the party who hires a real estate agent must also pay the agent’s commission. The goal is to reduce financial burdens on tenants.

This regulation has the following effects:

Tenants do not have to pay brokerage fees unless they have hired the agent themselves.
Landlords cover the agent’s costs if they hire a broker to find tenants.
Fairness and transparency in the real estate market are promoted since the cost burden lies with the client.
Legal Basis and Application
● The Ordering Principle primarily applies to rental apartments.
● It does not apply to property purchases, where buyers can still be required to pay brokerage fees.
● Violations of the principle can result in fines.

Example for Austria and Germany:
○ A tenant is looking for an apartment and contacts a real estate agent. Since the agent is working on behalf of the landlord, the tenant does not have to pay a commission.
○ However, if the tenant hires an agent independently to find a property, they must cover the agent’s fees.
○ Landlords attempting to pass brokerage costs onto tenants are acting illegally.

Responsible Authority: The respective tenant protection organization or real estate regulatory authority.

a4.title: Operating Costs
a4.descriptions:
The Operating Costs are ongoing expenses incurred for the maintenance and operation of a building. These costs are usually passed on to tenants and are regulated by the Operating Costs Ordinance (BetrKV).

Typical Operating Costs:

Property Tax – Tax on property ownership.
Water Supply and Wastewater Disposal – Fees for drinking water and wastewater removal.
Heating and Hot Water – Costs for room heating and hot water supply.
Garbage Collection and Street Cleaning – Waste disposal and cleaning of public areas.
Building Cleaning and Caretaker Services – Cleaning of communal areas and caretaker services.
Lighting of Common Areas – Electricity costs for stairwells, basements, and outdoor lighting.
Chimney Cleaning – Maintenance and inspection of heating systems.
Building Insurance – Insurance covering fire, water, and storm damages.
Caretaker Costs – Salary and labor costs of the caretaker.
Elevator Costs – Maintenance and repair of elevators.
Operating Cost Statement:
The statement is issued annually. If the tenant has overpaid, they receive a refund; otherwise, they must make an additional payment.

Responsible Authority: Landlord or property management.

a5.title: Easement
a5.descriptions:
An easement is a legal right that allows a person or entity to use someone else's property in a specific way or imposes certain restrictions on the owner.

There are different types of easements regulated by law:

Appurtenant Easement – The owner must tolerate certain rights granted to a neighboring property (e.g., right of way).
Personal Easement – Grants an individual the right to use a property or land (e.g., right of residence).
Usufruct – The beneficiary can use the property and receive economic benefits from it.
Utility Easement – Allows utility companies to lay electricity, water, or gas lines over a property.
Building Restrictions – Limitations on construction or use of land in favor of a third party.
Legal Aspects:
• Easements are recorded in the land register and remain binding for future owners.
• Removal is only possible with the consent of the involved parties or by legal regulation.

Costs and Responsibility:
• Fees apply for registration in the land register.
• Responsible entities include notaries, land registry offices, or relevant authorities.

a6.title: Real Estate Ownership Acquisition
a6.descriptions:
The acquisition of real estate in Austria is legally regulated and subject to certain conditions depending on factors such as nationality, property type, and financing method.

Basic Requirements for Acquisition:

Legal Capacity – The buyer must be of legal age and legally competent.
Valid Purchase Agreement – The contract must be notarized or drafted by a lawyer.
Land Register Entry – Ownership is only legally recognized after being recorded in the land register.
Financing – Payment can be made through own capital, bank loans, or other financing methods.
Acquisition by Foreigners:
• EU and EEA citizens – Treated equally as Austrian nationals, no approval required.
• Third-country nationals – Generally require official approval.
• Special Agreements – Some nationals may acquire property through bilateral agreements.

Additional Costs:
• Real estate transfer tax – 3.5% of the purchase price.
• Land register entry fee – 1.1% of the purchase price.
• Notary and legal fees – Variable, depending on the contract.

Responsible Authorities:
• Land registry office for registering the new owner.
• Notaries and lawyers for contract drafting.
• Tax authorities for handling tax payments.

a7.title: Energy Performance Certificate
a7.descriptions:
The Energy Performance Certificate (EPC) is an official document that assesses the energy efficiency of a building or apartment. It provides information about energy consumption and serves as a crucial guide for buyers and tenants. In Austria, the EPC is legally required and must be presented when selling or renting out a property.

Key Information in the Energy Performance Certificate:

Energy Rating – Indicates the building’s energy consumption per square meter per year (kWh/m²a).
Heating Demand (HWB) – Shows the annual heating energy requirement of a building.
Overall Energy Efficiency Factor (fGEE) – Compares the building’s efficiency to a reference building.
CO₂ Emissions – Calculates the environmental impact of energy consumption.
Recommended Measures – Suggests improvements to enhance energy efficiency.
Obligations for Owners and Landlords:
• A valid EPC must be provided when selling or renting out a property.
• The EPC must not be older than 10 years.
• The cost of issuing the certificate is usually covered by the owner.

Exceptions:
• Buildings with a usable floor area under 50 m².
• Heritage-protected buildings.
• Buildings used for seasonal purposes only (e.g., holiday homes).

Responsible Authorities:
• Energy advisory offices and certified EPC issuers.

a8.title: Maintenance Obligations
a8.descriptions:
Maintenance obligations refer to the legal and contractual responsibilities of owners and tenants to keep a building or apartment in proper condition. These obligations include structural maintenance, technical systems, and safety measures.

Owner’s Responsibilities:

Structural Maintenance – Ensuring that the building has no damages affecting safety or usability.
Technical Maintenance – Regular inspection and servicing of heating, water, ventilation, and electrical systems.
Safety Installations – Maintaining fire protection, lightning protection, and security systems.
Common Areas – Maintaining staircases, roofs, facades, and outdoor areas.
Compliance with Regulations – Implementing construction and safety regulations.
Tenant’s Responsibilities:
• Minor Repairs – Fixing small damages as part of normal use.
• Careful Usage – Preventing damage due to negligent behavior.
• Reporting Obligation – Immediately informing the landlord about major defects or damages.

Cost Regulation:
• Owner’s maintenance costs are usually included in the operating costs paid by tenants.
• Minor repairs may be the direct responsibility of the tenant.

Responsible Authorities:
• Property management, building inspection authorities, or specialized maintenance firms.

a9.title: Land Use Plans
a9.descriptions:
The land use plan is an official planning instrument that regulates the use of land within a municipality. It determines which areas are designated for residential, commercial, industrial, agricultural, or public purposes.

Main Land Use Categories:

Building Land – Areas designated for residential, commercial, or industrial buildings.
Green Land – Areas reserved for agriculture or recreational purposes.
Traffic Areas – Roads, paths, squares, and other infrastructure facilities.
Importance of the Land Use Plan:
• Legal Basis – Defines the permitted use of a plot and serves as the foundation for building procedures.
• Sustainable Urban Planning – Helps ensure an orderly and environmentally friendly development.
• Impact on Property Value – Changes to the plan can significantly increase or decrease property value.

Approval Process:
• Changes to the land use plan must be approved by the municipality and the responsible regional authorities.
• Adjusting a land use plan can take several months to years.

Responsible Authority:
• The city or municipal administration and the state government.

a10.title: Land Register
a10.descriptions:
The Land Register is a public record that documents all properties, their ownership, and related rights or encumbrances. It ensures legal security and transparency in real estate transactions.

Main Components of the Land Register:

Main Register – Contains property descriptions, owner information, and rights.
Encumbrance Register – Lists mortgages, liens, and easements.
Document Collection – Includes contracts and documents that led to changes in ownership.
Key Functions:
• Legal Security – Ownership rights are legally protected and publicly accessible.
• Fraud Prevention – Only registered rights are legally binding.
• Mortgage Security – Banks use land register entries as collateral for loans.

Registration and Costs:
• Ownership transfers must be registered by a notary or lawyer.
• The registration fee is approximately 1.1% of the purchase price.

Responsible Authority:
• The local land registry office or district court.

a11.title: Land Register Entry Fee
a11.descriptions:
The land register entry fee is a legally mandated charge for registering a new property owner in the land register. It is an essential part of the additional costs when purchasing real estate.

Amount of the Fee:

Ownership registration: 1.1% of the purchase price or property value.
Mortgage registration: 1.2% of the loan amount, if a mortgage is taken.
Gifts or inheritance: Reduced rates may apply depending on the region.
Example Calculation:
• Purchase price: €300,000
• Land register entry fee: €3,300 (1.1% of €300,000)

Who Pays the Fee?
• Usually, the buyer pays the land register entry fee.
• If financing is secured through a mortgage, the mortgage entry fee must also be paid.

Payment and Due Date:
• The fee is paid to the land registry office.
• Payment is usually handled by the notary or lawyer processing the transaction.

Responsible Authority:
• Land registry office at the local district court.

a12.title: Real Estate Transfer Tax
a12.descriptions:
The Real Estate Transfer Tax is a legally mandated tax levied on the purchase or transfer of real estate in Austria. It is calculated based on the purchase price or market value of the property and represents a key cost in real estate transactions.

Tax Rates for Real Estate Transfers:

Standard Rate: 3.5% of the purchase price or property value.
Reduced Rate: 0.5% to 2%, applicable for transfers within families.
Gifts and Inheritances: Progressive tax rates apply depending on the degree of relationship.
Example Calculation:
• Property purchase price: €400,000
• Real estate transfer tax (3.5%): €14,000

Who Pays the Real Estate Transfer Tax?
• Typically, the buyer is responsible for paying the tax.
• In cases of inheritance or gifts, the new owner is liable for the tax.

Payment and Due Date:
• The tax must be paid to the tax office within one month after signing the contract.
• The amount is calculated by the tax office or a notary.

Responsible Authority:
• Tax Office and Land Registry Office.

a13.title: House Rules
a13.descriptions:
The house rules are binding regulations for all residents of an apartment building and define how communal living is organized. They aim to prevent conflicts and ensure safety and order in the building.

Typical Regulations in House Rules:

Quiet Hours – Specific times when noise must be minimized (e.g., 10:00 PM – 6:00 AM).
Cleaning Duties – Specifies who is responsible for cleaning staircases, hallways, and shared areas.
Waste Disposal – Rules for waste separation and garbage collection schedules.
Pets – Clarifies whether pets are allowed and under what conditions.
Use of Common Areas – Regulations for laundry rooms, basements, bike storage, or gardens.
Safety Measures – Guidelines for locking entrance doors and using elevators.
Legal Significance:
• House rules are part of the rental agreement and must be followed by all tenants.
• Violations can result in warnings or even termination of the lease.

Responsible Authority:
• Landlord, property management, or owners’ association.

a14.title: Real Estate Capital Gains Tax
a14.descriptions:
The Real Estate Capital Gains Tax (ImmoESt) is a tax levied in Austria on profits from the sale of real estate, including land, houses, and apartments. It applies when the selling price exceeds the original purchase price.

Tax Rates:

Standard rate: 30% on the profit from the sale.
Old cases (properties acquired before 2002): Reduced tax rates of 4.2% or 18%.
Exemptions from taxation:
● Primary residence exemption – If the property was used as a main residence for at least 2 consecutive years or 5 out of the last 10 years.
● Self-construction exemption – If the seller built the property themselves.
Example Calculation:
• Selling price: €400,000
• Original purchase price: €300,000
• Profit: €100,000
• Capital gains tax (30% of €100,000): €30,000

Who Pays the Tax?
• Sellers who sell a property at a profit.
• The tax is deducted directly by the notary or lawyer and forwarded to the tax office.

Payment and Deadline:
• The tax must be paid immediately after the sale.

Responsible Authority:
• Tax Office and Land Registry Office.

a15.title: Security Deposit
a15.descriptions:
The security deposit is a sum of money paid by a tenant to the landlord as financial security. It covers potential damage to the rental property or unpaid rent. If no claims exist, the deposit is refunded at the end of the lease.

Deposit Amount:

Usually 3 months' rent, but a maximum of 6 months' rent.
Can be deposited in cash, on a locked account, or via a bank guarantee.
The landlord is required to store the deposit with interest.
Refund of the Deposit:
• Paid back after termination of the rental agreement.
• The landlord can only withhold the deposit for proven damages or outstanding claims.
• If disputes arise, the refund process can be resolved through a conciliation board or court.

Responsible Authority:
• Landlord, tenant associations, or conciliation boards.

a16.title: Types of Rent
a16.descriptions:
The rent is the payment made by a tenant for the use of a property. In Austria, there are different types of rent, depending on the type of lease agreement and legal regulations.

Main Types of Rent:

Base Rent (Hauptmietzins) – The actual amount paid for using the property.
Operating Costs (Nebenmietzins) – Charges for water, garbage collection, cleaning, and shared expenses.
Maintenance and Improvement Contribution – Payment for necessary repairs and renovations.
Gross Rent (Bruttomietzins) – The total rent, including all costs.
Net Rent (Nettomietzins) – The rent amount excluding operating costs and taxes.
Special Rent Forms:
• Reference Value Rent (Richtwertmietzins) – A legally regulated maximum rent for older buildings.
• Category Rent (Kategorie-Mietzins) – An older rent model for low-standard apartments.
• Free Market Rent (Freier Mietzins) – Applies to new buildings and is not legally limited.

Payment and Due Date:
• Rent is usually paid monthly in advance.
• Payment can be made via bank transfer, standing order, or cash payment.

Responsible Authority:
• Landlord, tenant associations, or conciliation boards.

a17.title: Rent Calculation
a17.descriptions:
Rent calculation defines how rent is structured in Austria and what legal regulations apply. The calculation depends on various factors such as the type of lease, the location of the property, and the building’s construction year.

Main Factors in Rent Calculation:

Reference Value Rent (Richtwertmietzins) – Applies to old buildings (built before 1945) with a legally set maximum price per m².
Category Rent (Kategorie-Mietzins) – Used for apartments with lower housing standards in older buildings.
Free Market Rent (Freier Mietzins) – Applies to new buildings or properties not subject to rent control.
Operating Costs (Betriebskosten) – Additional costs for garbage collection, water, cleaning, and maintenance.
Maintenance and Improvement Contributions – Fees for necessary renovations and modernizations.
Legal Regulations:
• Rent must be reasonable and not excessive.
• In certain cases, tenants can request a rent review through the arbitration board or the court.
• Rent increases must comply with legal guidelines.

Responsible Authority:
• Tenant associations, arbitration boards, or courts.

a18.title: Additional Costs for Renting a Residential Property
a18.descriptions:
When renting a residential property, tenants must pay additional operating costs besides the base rent. These are monthly payments covering various services related to the property’s upkeep.

Typical Additional Costs:

Operating Costs – Fees for garbage collection, water, cleaning, and building maintenance.
Heating and Hot Water Costs – Often billed separately based on consumption.
Electricity Costs – Paid directly by the tenant to the electricity provider.
Insurance Costs – Contributions to building insurance, usually passed on by the landlord.
Property Management Fees – Costs for property administration (e.g., janitorial services).
Security Deposit – Typically three months’ rent, refunded at the end of the lease.
Broker’s Commission – If the apartment was rented through an agent, a fee may apply.
Example Calculation:
• Base Rent: €700
• Operating Costs: €150
• Heating Costs: €80
• Total Monthly Costs: €930

Payment and Billing:
• Additional costs are billed as a flat rate or based on actual usage.
• Once a year, tenants receive a detailed cost statement, which may result in extra payment or refund.

Responsible Authority:
• Landlord, property management, utility providers.

contact-provider.title: CONTACT THE PROVIDER
contact-provider.p1: This magnificent residence is located high above the rolling hills and offers an incomparable view down over Vienna and the surrounding picturesque landscape. The spacious entrance area immediately conveys a feeling of luxury, comfort and exclusivity. The floor-to-ceiling windows in the central living area flood the room with natural light and offer a magical view of the green oasis of the property's own garden, which blends harmoniously into the panoramic landscape. The fitness room with indoor pool, whirlpool and sauna offers everything you need to strengthen and relax your body and mind. The spacious garage has an electric charging station and offers parking for three cars. The outdoor area of this property offers breathtaking views and plenty of space for terraces, barbecues, sports activities and even an outdoor sauna.
contact-provider.p2: Klosterneuburg is a town of rich history, magnificent architecture and an idyllic location along the Danube. The town offers a first-class infrastructure with good transport links, high-quality educational institutions, comprehensive healthcare and a wide range of shopping opportunities. Numerous recreational facilities, including sports clubs and parks, as well as a vibrant cultural scene with museums and cultural events, enrich urban life. Ölberg, a picturesque district in Klosterneuburg, offers not only an idyllic residential location but also breathtaking views of Vienna, which lies at its feet. Well-planned transport links allow residents to quickly reach the city centre of Klosterneuburg, Vienna and beyond. This allows them to enjoy the benefits of country life while benefiting from the amenities and well-developed infrastructure of the big cities.
contact-provider.provider-descr: By pressing the "Send Message" button, you agree that fylpi and its partners and real estate professionals may call/message you regarding your inquiry, possibly using automated means and pre-recorded/artificial voices. You do not have to consent in order to purchase a property, goods or services. Message and data rates may apply. You also agree to our Terms of Use. Fylpi does not endorse any specific real estate professionals. We may share information about your recent and future activity on the Site with your agent to help them understand what you are looking for in a home.

how-buy-property.question: How can I buy a property?
how-buy-property.answer: To sell your property, you will generally need a current land register extract, an energy certificate, building plans and floor plans, as well as, if necessary, rental agreements and evidence of renovations carried out. These documents help make the sales process smooth. So you are well prepared.

documents-need-to-sell-property.question: What documents do I need to sell my property?
documents-need-to-sell-property.answer:
When selling your property, you need several important documents. One of the key documents is an extract from the land register, which proves your ownership. Additionally, an energy certificate is legally required to provide information about the property's energy efficiency. If available, you should also have construction plans and floor plans, as they help potential buyers better understand the layout of the property.

If you have carried out any renovations or modernizations in the past, it is useful to provide proof of these works. If the property is currently rented, you will also need rental agreements and an overview of the utility bills.

To ensure you have all the necessary documents, it is advisable to check with the relevant authorities or consult a real estate agent in advance.

how-find-best-rental-offers.question: How do I find the best rental offers near me?
how-find-best-rental-offers.answer:
To find the best rental offers in your area, there are several effective strategies. One of the easiest ways is to use online real estate portals, where you can filter listings based on price, size, and amenities. Popular platforms include Zillow, Apartments.com, and Craigslist.

Additionally, contacting local real estate agents can be very useful, as they often have exclusive rental listings that are not publicly advertised online. Checking local newspaper ads or looking for "For Rent" signs in your neighborhood can also help you discover hidden gems.

Another great option is to explore social media platforms or local Facebook groups, where landlords often post available rentals. You can also create your own post stating what kind of property you are looking for, which might attract potential landlords.

If you want to secure a rental quickly, it's important to check new listings frequently and contact the landlord as soon as possible to schedule a viewing.

costs-associated-property.question: What costs are associated with buying a property?
costs-associated-property.answer:
When purchasing a property, there are additional costs beyond the purchase price that buyers should be aware of. One of the most significant is the real estate transfer tax, which varies by region and typically ranges between 3.5% and 6.5% of the purchase price. Additionally, notary and land registry fees usually amount to 1.5% to 2% of the total cost.

If you hire a real estate agent, you may need to pay a broker's commission, which is typically between 3% and 7% of the property's price, depending on the agreement and location. You should also factor in potential renovation, modernization, or moving expenses.

Financing a property can also come with extra costs, such as bank processing fees or early repayment penalties if you decide to pay off a loan ahead of schedule. After the purchase, ongoing expenses like property taxes, insurance, and maintenance costs should also be considered.

It is advisable to calculate all these costs in advance and seek advice from a financial expert or real estate professional to ensure a well-planned investment.

how-arrange-viewing-appointment.question: How can I arrange a viewing appointment?
how-arrange-viewing-appointment.answer:
There are several ways to schedule a property viewing. In most cases, you can contact the seller or landlord directly through the real estate platform where the listing was published. Many online portals provide a contact form or a direct phone number for the seller or real estate agent.

If the property is listed through an agent, you can reach out via phone or email to arrange a suitable appointment. It’s advisable to suggest multiple time slots to increase the chances of securing a viewing.

If you found a property through a newspaper ad or a "For Sale" or "For Rent" sign, you can call the owner directly or visit the location to inquire about a viewing.

Before the appointment, it's a good idea to prepare a list of important questions about the property. If you’re looking to rent, having documents such as a tenant self-disclosure form, proof of income, or a credit report ready can improve your chances of getting the property.

register-on-platform.question: How can I register on the platform?
register-on-platform.answer: You can register by clicking the "Sign Up" button and entering your email address and a secure password.

reset-password.question: How can I reset my password?
reset-password.answer: Click on "Forgot password" on the login page and follow the instructions to create a new password.

edit-delete-listing.question: Is it possible to edit or delete a listing?
edit-delete-listing.answer: Yes, you can edit or delete your listings anytime in your user account.

customer-support.question: How can I contact customer support?
customer-support.answer: You can reach us via email at support@fylpi.at or by phone at +43 699 1700 20045.

find-rental-property.question: How can I find a rental property on this platform?
find-rental-property.answer: You can use the search filters to find properties based on location, price, size, and amenities. Click on a listing to view details and contact the landlord.

contact-landlord.question: How do I contact a landlord about a property?
contact-landlord.answer: Once you find a suitable rental, you can contact the landlord directly through the contact form on the listing page.

register-rent.question: Do I need to register to rent a property?
register-rent.answer: Yes, registration is required to contact landlords and save favorites. Signing up is free.

costs-involved-renting.question: What costs are involved in renting through this platform?
costs-involved-renting.answer: Using the platform is free. However, you may have to pay a security deposit and possibly an agent fee if applicable.

safe-rent-property.question: How safe is it to rent a property through this website?
safe-rent-property.answer: All listings are verified, and we recommend reviewing all documents carefully before signing a contract and never making advance payments.

sell-property.question: How can I sell a property on this platform?
sell-property.answer: You can create a listing through your user account by adding all relevant details, photos, and the price.

documents-to-sell.question: What documents do I need to sell my property?
documents-to-sell.answer: Common documents include the title deed, energy certificate, floor plans, and rental agreements (if applicable).

how-long-sell.question: How long does it take to sell a property?
how-long-sell.answer: The duration depends on demand, pricing, and location. A professional listing can speed up the sale.

edit-remove-listing.question: Can I edit or remove my listing after posting?
edit-remove-listing.answer: Yes, you can edit or delete your listing at any time in your user account.

costs-involved-selling.question: Are there any costs involved in selling my property?
costs-involved-selling.answer: Using the platform is free, but fees for real estate agents or notary services may apply.

rent-out-property.question: How can I rent out a property on this platform?
rent-out-property.answer: You can create a listing through your user account by adding all relevant details, photos, and rental conditions.

documents-to-rent-out.question: What documents do I need to rent out a property?
documents-to-rent-out.answer: Typically, you need proof of ownership, an energy certificate, and a rental agreement for the tenant.

quickly-find-tenant.question: How can I quickly find a suitable tenant?
quickly-find-tenant.answer: A detailed listing, high-quality photos, and a competitive rental price help attract tenants faster.

edit-remove-listing.question: Can I edit or remove my listing after posting?
edit-remove-listing.answer: Yes, you can edit or delete your listing at any time in your user account.

any-costs-landlords.question: Are there any costs for landlords?
any-costs-landlords.answer: Using the platform is free, but you may incur costs for real estate agents or legal services.

can-not-log-account.question: I can't log into my account. What should I do?
can-not-log-account.answer: Make sure you entered your email and password correctly. If you forgot your password, click on “Forgot password” and follow the instructions.

listing-not-displaying.question: My listing is not displaying correctly. How can I fix this?
listing-not-displaying.answer: Check if all required information is provided. If the issue persists, contact our support team.

can-change-account-settings.question: How can I change my account settings?
can-change-account-settings.answer: You can update your personal details, email, and password in the account settings under "My Account."

not-receiving-emails-from-platform.question: I’m not receiving emails from the platform. What can I do?
not-receiving-emails-from-platform.answer: Check your spam folder and make sure our email address is not blocked.

contact-support.question: How can I contact customer support?
contact-support.answer: You can reach us via email at support@fylpi.at or by phone at +43 699 1700 20045.

7.descriptions:
The customer expressly acknowledges that fylpi or third parties hold the exclusive copyright and performance protection rights for the overall appearance as well as individual parts of advertisements created by fylpi, advertisements posted by third parties, and other content published on www.fylpi.at (such as texts, trademarks, photos, databases, layouts, etc.). Unless otherwise agreed in writing with the customer, the payment of fees does not transfer any rights to the advertiser.

The customer is therefore not entitled to use advertisements created by fylpi outside of fylpi websites unless otherwise agreed in writing with fylpi.

The customer is not permitted to influence the design of fylpi’s websites or advertisements (e.g., visually or structurally).

By submitting or uploading (via self-entry, data interface, etc.) an advertisement, the advertiser, either on their own behalf or on behalf of the rights holder, grants fylpi the exclusive and transferable right to distribute, modify, edit, publish, and make these contents publicly available indefinitely in terms of time and geography within fylpi and its partner/corporate media. This right also includes the use of the advertisements for fylpi’s self-promotion.

fylpi has the right, but not the obligation, to defend against unlawful infringements of the usage rights transferred to fylpi in its own name and to assert any resulting claims in court if necessary. The advertiser must fully support fylpi in such defense cases. The advertiser must immediately and in writing inform fylpi of any third-party claims made against them.

8.descriptions:
fylpi bears no responsibility for advertisements going online at a certain time and/or being deactivated/deleted.
fylpi is not liable for a specific success of an advertisement or for the enforceability of a contract concluded via the marketplace (e.g. purchase of a property). fylpi is also not liable for the goods, services, etc. offered on the marketplace, neither for warranty or guarantee, nor for damages, product liability, etc. Property, goods, services, etc. offered do not represent binding offers from fylpi. fylpi is neither an agent nor a broker. fylpi has no obligation whatsoever to obtain or pass on further information about the goods, services, etc. offered/advertised by customers.
If retrievable content or advertisements are posted and made accessible by customers or on their behalf, fylpi assumes no liability whatsoever for the content, accuracy, timeliness or reliability, misuse, spelling and transmission errors, etc., of customer identity details or the accessibility of persons based on the information provided.
The customer of the Internet service declares that he will only use the Internet service within the framework of the contractual or legal provisions and without violating the rights of third parties. In particular, the customer declares that he will not use, edit, falsify, delete or make unrecognizable the copyright, competition law, trademark protection and other rights of third parties without their consent.
The customer declares that he will in any case fully indemnify and hold fylpi harmless from any claims by third parties that are based on his area of ​​responsibility. The customer therefore undertakes to indemnify and hold fylpi harmless (legal and court costs) in the event that fylpi is sued for civil or criminal, judicial or extrajudicial content posted and thus published by the customer, in particular through private prosecutions for insult, slander, damage to reputation under the criminal law or through proceedings under the Media Act, the Copyright Act and other intellectual property rights, the UWG (Law against Unfair Competition) or for civil defamation and/or damage to reputation (Section 1330 of the Austrian Civil Code).
fylpi's warranty to customers only extends to the reproduction of the paid advertisement in accordance with the current technical standard and to the corresponding availability of data. Free advertisements or services (search agent, watch lists, delivery of inquiries) do not entitle the customer to assert claims. No liability is accepted and no compensation is provided for errors that do not significantly affect the meaning of the advertisement.
fylpi is not liable for damages that result to the customer from the misuse of data transmitted to third parties (e.g. in advertisements, emails, applications, recommendations, etc.).
The advertisements created or modified automatically or manually by fylpi always represent only a draft that must be approved by the customer after a thorough factual and legal review.Complaints: Complaints of all kinds about the advertisement must be reported to fylpi in writing and stating the reason for the complaint by the advertiser - unless the advertisement was entered/changed by the advertiser - immediately and no later than within 2 working days after the advertisement was published/changed. After that, the advertisement is deemed to be free of defects.
If a paid advertisement has a defect for which fylpi is responsible, the advertiser is entitled, at fylpi's discretion, to a new initial advertisement in the scope of the advertisement on which the defect is based. If an improvement fails within a reasonable period of time, the advertiser can only demand a price reduction after a further reasonable period of time and an attempt to improve the advertisement has been made. The advertiser is not entitled to any further claims - unless otherwise required by law.
The advertiser is responsible for the correct entry of the advertisements, especially in the case of self-entry; photos and other material must be entered in the menu-defined format in perfect condition. fylpi cannot provide any guarantee whatsoever for the accuracy of advertisements or changes placed by telephone.
Customers are responsible for securing and storing data they require (e.g. for order processing, securing evidence, archiving, etc.) using an independent/external storage medium. fylpi is entitled to delete all data including photos 3 months after expiration/deletion (deactivation, etc.) of the advertisement.
fylpi is not liable for the compatibility of the Internet service with the hardware and software, for constant availability, for viruses, misuse or damage caused by improper use by the customer due to unsuitable hardware and software used, or for malfunctions caused by the Internet connection or otherwise resulting from the use of the data or the Internet service. Customers are also responsible for which links they use.
fylpi is also not liable for a failure of fylpi's servers that lasts no longer than 3% but at least 48 hours within the contractually agreed switching period. fylpi points out that fylpi can limit or temporarily stop its services for necessary reasons (e.g. maintenance, security, capacity, improvement reasons). These measures do not constitute a failure and cannot be added to a downtime, even if they are carried out in the same service period in which a failure occurs.
fylpi expressly points out that the unauthorized production of copies, unauthorized linking (framing) or publication of advertisements disguised as a third party's own offer cannot be completely ruled out. fylpi will endeavor to prevent these practices as far as technically and legally possible and reasonable. The advertiser hereby grants fylpi any necessary consent to do so. However, the advertiser has no claims against fylpi for unauthorized practices by third parties that nevertheless occur.
If fylpi is liable for damages according to the statutory provisions, fylpi's liability is limited to intent and gross negligence. Any further liability of fylpi, in particular for slight negligence, atypical damages, lost profits, damages due to defects, indirect and consequential damages, damages to third parties, etc. is excluded. In any case, fylpi's liability is limited to the amount/price of the order in question with the customer. The burden of proof for fylpi's negligence lies with the customer. Claims for damages expire within six months in any case. This applies subject to mandatory statutory provisions to the contrary (e.g. Consumer Protection Act).

fylpi's liability for damages due to force majeure (e.g. strikes, war crimes, earthquakes) is excluded.

9.1.title: 9.1. General
9.1.descriptions:
Unless otherwise agreed, the fees resulting from the currently valid price list apply, which can be viewed at www.fylpi.at in the respective advertisement (price lists for package offers can be requested at office@fylpi.at). fylpi reserves the right to charge customers fees, e.g. for additional options or for the use of services, etc. The prices are listed in the price list for additional options. Customers bear all costs and expenses associated with their payment (e.g. transfer), such as bank charges, handling fees. Amounts/prices to be paid by the consumer include statutory VAT, duties and other surcharges (gross prices).
Payment is generally made before the service is activated (e.g. advertisement, additional option, service, etc.) and must be made using the possible payment methods listed by fylpi (credit card, online banking or via vouchers, prepaid credit, etc.).
fylpi is entitled to issue a total invoice for all fylpi services; this is regardless of whether these services are owed under different contracts.
When paying via our payment provider, an invoice can be requested upon request by activating the option and entering the master data. When paying by payment slip, an invoice can be requested from the respective display in the user account. This invoice is only sent by email.
fylpi reserves the right to round amounts up or down to 1 full cent.
Invoices must be complained about within 14 days of receipt, otherwise they are deemed to have been accepted by the customer.
For payment receipts, the commercial customer must provide the customer number and the private customer must provide their user name (email address). The costs of research that would otherwise arise will be invoiced to the customer. The payment only has the debt-discharging effect once it has been correctly assigned.
When paying by credit card or direct debit, the customer must ensure that the credit card or account is not blocked or expired; otherwise, any delays in payment resulting from this will be at the customer's expense. In this case, the customer may be charged interest on late payment.
If payment is processed on the platform via a payment provider, fylpi is not liable for the security of the data or incorrect bookings caused by errors on the part of the payment provider.
fylpi reserves the right to offer payment for individual advertisements or additional options or services using previously topped up credit (prepaid). In this case, customers must purchase sufficient credit. Customers can view their account balance at any time in their "advertisement management". Complaints must be made within 14 days of the last change, otherwise the account is deemed to be accepted.
Prepaid vouchers or credit topped up via a payment provider are valid for 12 months. Unused credit will not be refunded.
fylpi is not liable for any misuse, theft, loss, etc. of the access data, credit or other data and/or information associated with the credit account for which fylpi is not responsible.
If the advertiser fails to meet delivery deadlines and therefore the advertisement cannot be published or cannot be published on time, this does not affect fylpi's right to payment of the agreed remuneration. This also applies if fylpi justifiably blocks the advertiser or deletes the advertisement for reasons for which the advertiser is responsible.
Special provisions for commercial customers:
The prices are exclusive of statutory sales tax and all other applicable fees, taxes and duties (e.g. 5% advertising tax).
If taxes or other duties are subsequently introduced or prescribed, these are at the customer's expense.

9.2.title: 9.2. Invoicing for Package Contracts (only for commercial customers)
9.2.descriptions:
Ad packages are invoiced directly to the customer. However, it is possible to purchase additional ads, services, placements, and additional options (e.g., top ads, priority placement, services) directly in the administration area. Payment for these is made immediately upon booking through the payment provider. fylpi reserves the right to collectively invoice additional options and extra advertisements within a billing period.

Invoices must be paid immediately and in full upon receipt, unless otherwise agreed.

If advertisement prices change, the new conditions apply immediately, even for ongoing contracts. For any prepaid periods, the price remains fixed. The new price applies from the next billing cycle. Price adjustments will be announced in advance.

The timeliness of payment is determined by the receipt/credit entry on fylpi’s account. In case of doubt, payments are applied to the oldest outstanding debt of the customer.

In case of payment default, fylpi is entitled to suspend services immediately or terminate the contract with immediate effect without prior notice, and the customer has no claims (e.g., for damages). However, fylpi’s claim to the agreed remuneration for the contract duration remains unaffected. Any granted discounts or price reductions will be revoked in case of contract termination, and fylpi is entitled to charge the standard rate as per the price list. The customer must pay any outstanding differences from the contract start.

If payment is delayed, the customer will be charged statutory default interest according to § 352 UGB. Additionally, the customer must cover all costs incurred in debt collection, such as reminder and collection fees, as well as legal and court costs.

Withholding payments and offsetting the customer’s claims against fylpi’s claims are excluded.

fylpi reserves the right to adjust the contract/billing start date, even if a different date was agreed upon in the contract, to the 1st or 15th of the month and prorate charges accordingly for the period before or after this date.

9.3.title: 9.3. Invoice Format for Package Contracts (only for commercial customers)
9.3.descriptions:
Customers receive invoices and payment reminders in paper form. fylpi reserves the right to switch the invoicing method to electronic invoices in accordance with legal requirements. Customers will receive all necessary information about the transition and requirements in writing at least one month in advance. If customers wish to continue receiving paper invoices after the switch to electronic invoicing, fylpi reserves the right to charge a fee (e.g., environmental fee, processing fee), provided this is legally permitted.

If invoices are sent via email, customers will receive them at the specified email address. Invoices can also be viewed and downloaded in the administration area. Customers must review them immediately. fylpi points out that an automatic debit authorization is required for electronic invoicing.

The invoice is considered received as soon as the customer can reasonably be expected to retrieve or acknowledge it (e.g., when the email is received).

If the customer chooses the direct debit payment method and it cannot be processed for reasons beyond fylpi’s control (e.g., due to insufficient funds or failure to update bank details), fylpi is entitled to switch the payment method to bank transfer without prior notice to the customer. For each failed direct debit transaction, fylpi is entitled to charge the customer any applicable bank fees and a reasonable processing fee.

10.1.title: 10.1. General
10.1.descriptions: The termination of the contractual relationship by fylpi via email is sufficient and is considered received upon confirmation of delivery by the customer's server or mail service.

10.2.title: 10.2. Notice for Consumers Regarding Paid Services (e.g., Paid Ad Placement)

10.3.title: 10.2.1. Notice of Consumer's Right of Withdrawal under § 3 KSchG
10.3.descriptions:
If the consumer has not made their contract declaration in the entrepreneur's premises used for business purposes or at a stand used by the entrepreneur at a trade fair or market, they may withdraw from their contract application or the contract. This withdrawal can be declared up until the contract is concluded or within 14 days thereafter. The period begins with the delivery of a document that includes at least the name and address of the entrepreneur, the necessary contract identification details, and instructions on the right of withdrawal, the withdrawal period, and the procedure for exercising the right of withdrawal, but not before the contract is concluded. In the case of purchase contracts for goods, the period starts when the consumer takes possession of the goods.

If such a document is not provided, the consumer has a right of withdrawal for a period of twelve months and 14 days from the contract conclusion or delivery of goods. If the entrepreneur subsequently provides the document within these twelve months, the extended withdrawal period ends 14 days after the consumer receives the document.

The consumer does not have the right of withdrawal:
1. if they initiated the business relationship with the entrepreneur or their representative for the purpose of concluding this contract,
2. if no prior discussion took place between the parties or their representatives before the contract was concluded, or
3. for contracts where both parties' services must be rendered immediately, if they are typically concluded outside business premises and the agreed amount does not exceed 25 euros, or if the business is not operated in permanent premises and the amount does not exceed 50 euros, or
4. for contracts subject to the Distance and Off-Premises Contracts Act or the Insurance Contract Act.

There is no specific form required for the withdrawal declaration. The withdrawal period is met if the withdrawal declaration is sent within the deadline.

10.4.title: 10.2.2. Right of Withdrawal under FAGG
10.4.descriptions:
Right of Withdrawal:
You have the right to withdraw from this contract within fourteen days without providing any reason.
The withdrawal period is fourteen days from the date of contract conclusion.

To exercise your right of withdrawal, you must inform us, fylpi (fylpi Immo-online GmbH, Forchheimergasse 3/13, 1230 Vienna, office@fylpi.at), of your decision to withdraw from this contract by means of a clear declaration (e.g., by mail or email). You may use the attached sample withdrawal form, but it is not mandatory.

To meet the withdrawal deadline, it is sufficient for you to send the notification of exercising your right of withdrawal before the withdrawal period expires.

Consequences of Withdrawal:
If you withdraw from this contract, we will refund all payments received from you, including delivery costs (except for additional costs incurred if you chose a type of delivery other than the cheapest standard delivery offered by us), without undue delay and at the latest within fourteen days from the day on which we received notice of your withdrawal from this contract. For this refund, we will use the same payment method that you used in the original transaction unless expressly agreed otherwise; in no case will you be charged fees for this refund.

If you requested that the services begin during the withdrawal period, you must pay us a reasonable amount corresponding to the proportion of the services already provided up to the time you inform us of your withdrawal, relative to the full scope of the services stipulated in the contract.

No Right of Withdrawal:
Warning: Your right of withdrawal expires prematurely if we have fully performed the service owed and only started execution after you expressly agreed to it and at the same time confirmed your knowledge that you would lose your right of withdrawal upon complete fulfillment of the contract. The service from fylpi is considered fully rendered upon activation.

The customer may deactivate their advertisement (or additional product, service, etc.) at any time before the agreed period ends. However, this does not constitute a withdrawal under KSchG or FAGG. The customer remains obliged to pay the full agreed fee.

10.5.title: 10.3. Termination of Contract for Self-Registration (Private/Commercial)
10.5.descriptions:
Contracts based on these Terms and Conditions can be terminated by the customer at any time by deleting their account. After termination of the contract, the user no longer has access to the information they have provided or generated. Legal rights of the user (especially data protection rights) remain unaffected.

fylpi is entitled to terminate the contract at any time for important reasons (extraordinary termination). Important reasons include, in particular, those stated in section 5.3.

10.6.title: 10.4. Termination of Package/Banner Contract
10.6.descriptions:
Contracts based on these Terms and Conditions may be terminated for one of the following reasons:
- Expiration of the agreed contract term
- If a termination option has been agreed upon, 30 days before the contract's main due date
- Consumption of an agreed quota
- Discontinuation of services by fylpi

fylpi is entitled to terminate the contract at any time for important reasons (extraordinary termination). Important reasons include, in particular, those stated in section 5.3.

An ordinary or extraordinary termination by the customer must be made in writing; an email is sufficient. However, in the case of an email, the termination is only considered received upon written confirmation from fylpi.

After termination of the contract, the user no longer has access to the information they have provided or generated. Legal rights of the user (especially data protection rights) remain unaffected.

11.1.title: 11.1. Confidentiality
11.1.descriptions: Information, data, documents, trade and business secrets, ideas, know-how, codes, etc. (hereinafter referred to as "Information") that become known to the customer in the course of the business relationship with fylpi are subject to strict confidentiality, regardless of how they were received (electronically, in print, etc.). Exceptions include information that is already publicly known or otherwise publicly accessible or explicitly designated as non-confidential by fylpi. The customer is therefore prohibited from using confidential information for purposes outside the contract or from disclosing it to third parties without authorization. The confidentiality obligation remains in effect even after the termination of the contract.

11.2.title: 11.2. Legal Succession
11.2.descriptions: All rights and obligations shall be transferred to legal successors (individual or universal succession). The transfer of rights and obligations to third parties is not permitted for the customer without the express prior written consent of fylpi.

11.3.title: 11.3. Written Form
11.3.descriptions: There are no verbal side agreements. Any changes and additions to agreements concluded via fylpi's online service must be in writing; this also applies to side agreements, assurances, and subsequent contract modifications, as well as waivers of the written form requirement.

11.4.title: 11.4. Severability Clause
11.4.descriptions: The invalidity of individual provisions does not affect the validity of the remaining provisions of these Terms and Conditions. An invalid provision shall be replaced by a valid provision that comes as close as possible to the economic and legal intent of the original. This shall also apply in the event of a gap in the provisions.

11.5.title: 11.5. Jurisdiction and Applicable Law
11.5.descriptions: All legal relationships between fylpi and the customers of the service are governed by Austrian law, excluding the reference norms of private international law (IPR) and the UN Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods. The place of performance is fylpi’s registered office. Unless mandatory provisions of consumer protection law dictate otherwise, the competent court in Vienna is agreed upon as the applicable jurisdiction.
